results.title: MSX Sony ‘Hit Bit’ HB-75B game console and accessories
results.material_description: Video games console with game controllers. Does not include computer monitor. Comes in box with manuals and several magazine advertisements for the unit. Object display only and not functioning
results.brief_description: MSX Sony ‘Hit Bit’ HB-75B video games console. Black computer unit includes keyboard with overlay and adhesive label sheet. Also included are MSX-Basic Reference Chart, Operating Instructions, Programming Reference Manual, Introduction to MSX-Basic, ‘Match Maker’ advertising flyers, aerial/TV/Computer cable and original packaging box.

results.title: Famicom: Nintendo Family Computer HVC-001
results.material_description: Video game console with game controllers.  Includes original box with transformer, power cord and computer user manual. Object display only and not functioning
results.brief_description: Famicom Nintendo Family Computer HVC-001 video games console unit. Red and white plastic computer unit with two gaming controllers attached by black power cords. Controllers have ports designed to rest them either side of the unit. Console comes in original packaging (box) with RF switch, power cable and manual. The manual is written in foreign language

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Alfred Milgrom]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Alfred Milgrom, with business partner and marketing expert Naomi Besen, launched Beam Software in 1980. From the company’s beginnings as UK publishing firm, Melbourne House, Milgrom and Besen moved to Australia and opened up their software programming arm with Beam. He reflects on his years in the software industry and the innovations Beam initiated, both in games design and corporate culture.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview 3]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Andrew Bailey and Trevor Nuridin discuss how they both entered the games industry and their work at Beam’s publishing arm, Melbourne House. They talk candidly about the culture at Beam and the reasons why they left to start Tantalus Media together in 1994.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Greg Barnett]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

After graudating in computer science from Melbourne University, Greg Bennett joined Beam Software in 1982. Inspired by his dual interests in programming and film, Bennett designed and programmed the groundbreaking one-on-one martial arts game ‘The Way of the exploding fist’. He talks about the game industry over the years and the changes, both financial and creative, in relation to his career.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Bill McIntosh]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Beam Software programmer, Bill McIntosh, left a boring job in the Royal Air Force to join Beam after his wife bought him a computer, which he equates with “plugging in his brain”. He discusses the games he worked on and the culture at Beam, and the financial conditions in Australia that put such companies at risk.

results.title: In conversation with Julian Rosefeldt
results.brief_description:
ACMI Curator Sarah Tutton speaks to acclaimed contemporary artist Julian Rosefeldt, offering a unique insight into his creative process.

German-born Rosefeldt makes visually opulent film and video installations. Following the exhibition of his 5-channel work ‘American Night’, Julian’s work ‘The Shift’ appeared as part of ACMI’s ‘Star Voyager’ exhibition in 2011. Rather than focussing on the exhibited work, Rosefeldt discusses his previous work, themes and influences, by way of prelude to his current projects.

This conversation provides the rare opportunity to hear one of the world’s most renowned moving image artists discuss his remarkable work.
